titleStmt.title: Ellen M. O'Connor to Walt Whitman, 21 December 1889
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Ellen M. O'Connor

sourceDesc.bibl: Ellen M. O'Connor Ellen M. O'Connor to Walt Whitman, 21 December 1889 December 21, 1889 MS18630, Box 14, Reel 8–9 The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

body.p:
I have just come from Oak Hill. My first visit to William's grave since last July when I went away. The ivy that we planted is growing well, & I plucked a few leaves
for you. By & by I can send you a root. Can you think that his body lies there? I can not realize it, yet I laid him away. How very strange it all is. It is a perfect day, & the dandelions are in bloom. Where do you think
William is, for that is only the worn out machine in which he manifested himself while here. I wonder & wonder, & think of it all so much, sometimes I almost feel him here.

I was glad of your letter. How I envy you your boy Horace! if
I had some one to give me a lift in my work, it would be a boon, but I guess my lesson in life is to learn to stand alone. I shall get to a place by & by where I shall have some report to make perhaps, but now there is nothing to show for it all. I, too, got a similar
announcement from Charles Eldridge, of his marriage. I hope that he will be very happy. I trust that all is as well as usual with you.

postscript.p: Some day I hope to get time to write to Dr. Bucke.
